abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Lessons indicate that: 1)
            in retrospect, the automated systems developed under the
            project, would have benefited, if input from eventual users
            would have been sought, and incorporated. Likewise, had
            feedback regarding registration offices operations, been
            requested in a more systematic process, the functioning of
            such offices would have improved gradually during
            implementation, and proceeded operationally, even farther;
            2) in the future, the Government should scrutinize the fee
            structure of registration systems, based on fees for
            service, which was beneficial to the quality of the system,
            so as to be able to raise the system's operational
            standards, through reduced costs, and commensurately, reduce
            the fees charged; 3) project implementation units (PIUs)
            could be monitored by the implementing agency, in respect to
            the implementation plan, and daily operations, a policy
            favored by the Government of Kazakhstan of transferring PIU
            functions to the implementing agencies, in lieu of hiring
            additional staff, or consultants to supplement
            implementation work; 4) higher level staff, with sufficient
            leverage over the agencies involved should be identified, to
            foster an effective, and successful project design; and, 5)
            technological system designs should be based on practical
            demands, and capabilities of end users, and not on an
            abstract technical conceptualization.
